results.title: Storm boy (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, South Australian Film Corporation and Henri Safran
results.brief_description: Three characters live in isolation amidst the coastal sand dunes of the Corrong in southern South Australia. In a shack on the beach live Tom, a fisherman and his young son; out amongst the dunes lives an aborigine, ‘Fingerbone Bill’ who forms a friendship with the boy, naming him ‘Storm Boy’. The story is conveyed with simplicity with many events left unspoken and undetailed. The relationships between the characters, and the scenes where the boy and his pet pelicans play together are subtley sketched and never lapse into the cloying sentimentality apparent in so many children’s films. Burton’s photography effectively captures the wild beauty of the Coorong.

results.title: Storm Boy
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, Henri Safran and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Storm Boy is a 1976 Australian drama film based on the book of the same name by Colin Thiele, about a lonely boy and his pet pelicans living in a coastal wilderness with his reclusive father.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.title: Storm
results.creator_credit: Second Banana Films and Steve French
results.brief_description: The fluid boundaries between love and hate in human affairs are given concrete form in this inventive animation as figures are continually metamorphosed to the Jazz classic ‘Stormy weather’.
results.description: The fluid boundaries between love and hate in human affairs are given concrete form in this inventive animation as figures are continually metamorphosed to the Jazz classic ‘Stormy weather’.

results.title: Stork
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Bilcock and Copping Film Productions and Tim Burstall and Associates
results.brief_description:
Adapted for the screen by David Williamson from his own stage play, Tim Burstall’s broad, low-budget comedy is one of the earliest, and most commercially successful, releases of the 1970s Australian film ‘renaissance’.

The adventures of the seven-foot-tall, Marcuse-quoting, would-be-revolutionary ‘ocker’, Stork, (Bruce Spence) satirise many aspects of contemporary Australian society and values. “The targets of its humour are the social goals and values of the middle-classes - conformity, ambition, marriage, the pretensions of the corporate world or the academic and art establishments.” (Tim Burstall).

results.title: Stories on a train = The Tale of Georgie Grub ...
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Butler’s Video Books”.
A video designed to encourage children to read and enjoy books. Ten different stories, many from well known books, are told by professional storytellers and have been selected for children aged five to eight years old. Introduced by Dorothy Butler. The stories are: “Troublesome pig”, ” The Grand old Duke of York”, “Grandma goes shopping”, “Lucky Hans”, “On Friday something funny happened”, “Wolf! Wolf!”, “The Tale of Georgie Grub”, “Everybody said no!”, “Mr. Biff the boxer” and “The Trouble with Jack”.

results.title: Stories of survival with Les Hiddins. [Part 2]
results.creator_credit: David Telfer, Richard Walker, Jack King, Tim Clark and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
Les Hiddins travels Australia-wide tracking down stories of survival in the wilderness. “Gold Fever” looks at the legend of Lasseter’s lost reef of gold in Central Australia. “The Passionate Prussian” retraces Leichardt’s exploration from Moreton Bay to Point Essington and the mystery which shrouds his disappearance. “The Great Misadventure” looks at the ill-fated Burke and Wills expedition and how a knowledge of Bush Tucker may have changed the outcome. The final episode “Into the Vilest Country” features the Cape York Penninsula as Les travels to the area in a manner which contrasts that of the cumbersome Kennedy exploration.

results.title: Stories of survival with Les Hiddins. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: David Telfer, Richard Walker, Tim Clark and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
Les Hiddins relates survival stories in four episodes. ‘The “Coffee Royal” affair’ set in Western Australia traces the story of Charles Kingsford Smith whose reputation was damaged by one of Australia’s earliest aviation disasters. ‘The Cannibal convict’ tells of one of the earliest convict escapees, Alexander Pierce in the wilds of south-west Tasmania. The footsteps of determined explorer John McDouall Stuart is retraced in ‘The Best of them all.’ ‘The Dutch settlement’ follows clues across Australia to investigate a report made last century about a Dutch colony established in Central Australia following a shipwreck.
